alert.note: Alert for Chester (Pennsylvania) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 18 at 7:48AM EST until December 19 at 3:16PM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 215 PM EST THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Portions of northern Delaware, including the following county, New Castle. Portions of southern New Jersey, including the following county, Gloucester. Portions of southeast Pennsylvania, including the following counties, Chester and Delaware. * WHEN...Until 215 PM EST Monday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 742 AM EST, rain gauges indicated 2 to 4 inches of rain have fallen since last evening. As a result, several USGS river gauges are above flood stage. Flooding will continue through the morning hours. - For Christina River at Newport: At 6:43am the stage was 8.13 feet. Flood Stage is 7.2 feet. ... For Crum Creek at Newtown Square: At 6:45am the stage was 8.65 feet. Flood Stage is 6 feet. ... For Ridley Creek at Media: At 7:30am the stage was 8.48 feet. Flood Stage is 7 feet. ... For Red Clay Creek at Stanton: At 7:15am the stage was 17.11 feet. Flood Stage is 17 feet. ... For Christina River at Wilmington: At 6:36am the stage was 6.89 feet. Flood Stage is 7.4 feet. ... For Shellpot Creek at Wilmington: At 6:55am the stage was 4.11 feet. Flood Stage is 8 feet. ... For Brandywine Creek at Wilmington: At 7:15am the stage was 15.74 feet. Flood Stage is 16.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Move to higher ground now. Act quickly to protect your life. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
